awd_titl_txt: Harmonic Analysis, Structure Theory of Measures, and Properties of Hamiltonian Dynamical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Harmonic analysis and geometric measure theory are important and fundamental mathematical disciplines to the study of partial differential equations and dynamical systems that arise from differential equations. The aim of this project is to add to the literature of these foundational subjects as well as to the study of a class of partial differential equations that are very important to modeling interaction of particles. Many types of physical phenomena, including the behavior of lasers through various types of media, thermalization of crystals, and optimal control, can be modeled by interacting particles or variational problems -- the two areas of research that benefit most from advances in geometric measure theory and harmonic analysis.

The scope of this research project includes the study of structures of measures via the examination of quantitative estimates of geometry, including measures of projections and point-wise densities. At the same time, this project entails the study of Hamiltonian dynamical systems as they relate to nonlinear dispersive PDEs, including nonlinear Schrodinger equations and various water wave equations. Specifically, we will study the question of stability of special solutions and integrability for the cubic nonlinear Schrodinger equation with data defined on compact domains of dimension greater than one. In addition, we will study the decay of the Favard length of neighborhoods of purely unrectifiable sets as well as Besicovitch's one-half problem and Falconer's distance set conjecture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project involved the study in three areas of mathematical analysis: harmonic analysis, geometric measure theory, and Hamiltonian dynamical systems. In the area of harmonic analysis, the PI made progress on the extent to which Fourier series converge for critically integrable functions on the torus. Three projects in the area of geometric measure theory were completed.  Specifically, the PI, along with collaborators, extended results in the area of characterizing rectifiability using singular integrals and densities in non-Euclidean geometries. The second project involved estimating the extent to which sets that are not necessarily rectifiable can be covered by recitifiable sets. The third project expanded on methods for approaching Falconer's distance set problem using new techniques originating in theoretical computer science. Finally, two manuscripts concerning dynamics of nonlinear Schrodinger equations in non-Euclidean geometries were completed. This includes one project on so-called waveguide manifolds which model fiber-optic cables.


Along with the main objectives of the project, the grant tangentially supported one postdoctoral fellow and one graduate student during the activity period. The postdoctoral fellow is now an assistant professor at the University of Oregon and the graduate student is finishing his studies this spring. Primarily, the grant funded the dissemination of the results described above as well as allowing the PI to establish and complete collaborative work.


Last Modified: 01/07/2025
Modified by: Bobby L Wilson
